It‚Äôs time for a candid discussion of what you did to Lt. Alkonis and his family. It‚Äôs time to heal this senseless wound. It‚Äôs time to #BringRidgeHome.
I love Japan, and am grateful for the relationship our countries have long enjoyed. Please keep it strong, and don‚Äôt weaken it as you have by imprisoning Lt. Alkonis.
And make no mistake, it will change if Lt. Alkonis isn‚Äôt back on U.S. soil by 11:59 pm EST on February 28, 2023.
I still hold out hope that you will. But my approach to all of this is about to change.

Out of respect for you and your relationship with the United States, there are a lot of us who have remained relatively quiet about all of this, hoping that it would give you the chance to do the right thing.
The fact that you‚Äîlike Lt. Alkonis‚Äîare far away from us doesn‚Äôt mean that your actions will go unnoticed here.

If you‚Äôre willing to do this to Lt. Alkonis, why should we trust that you won‚Äôt do the same to others? As our brave men and women are keeping you safe, what are you doing to make sure they‚Äôre treated fairly and respectfully?

If, however, he‚Äôs not on U.S. soil by then, many of us will work equally hard to make sure America knows (1) what a good security arrangement you have with the U.S., (2) what you did to one of the best and brightest our military has to offer, and (3) what we should do about it.
If you transfer Lt. Alkonis back to the U.S. before midnight on February 28, 2023, we will do our best to forget that this whole thing never happened. It will be hard, but we will try.

Why would you rock the boat by throwing one of our best and brightest in prison for three years‚Äîall because of a car accident that, tragic as it was, resulted from a non-foreseeable medical emergency.

Let‚Äôs face it, @kishida230, you‚Äôve got a really good security arrangement with the United States, and you‚Äôve had the luxury of not having that arrangement discussed or seriously questioned in Congress for a long time. That‚Äôs about to change.

You‚Äôve made whatever point you wanted to make by imprisoning him and claiming (quite misleadingly) that you‚Äôre treating him the same as you would a Japanese national. You‚Äôve made your point poorly and counterproductively, but whatever‚Äîit‚Äôs time to bring your standoff to an end.

You‚Äôve made whatever point you wanted to make by imprisoning him and claiming (quite misleadingly) that you‚Äôre treating him the same as you would a Japanese national. You‚Äôve made your point poorly and counterproductively, but whatever‚Äîit‚Äôs time to bring your standoff to an end.
Japan (I‚Äôm talking to you, @kishida230): U.S. Navy Lt. Ridge Alkonis needs to be back on U.S. soil no later than 11:59 pm EST on February 28, 2023.
